posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Hi, I am currently investigating ways to manage FRC teams, and I want to know what other people are doing.  Does anyone use Jira?  If so, how do you do it?  Do you use the Agile framework with another tool?  I am the software lead, so I am thinking first from the software standpoint.  But I would love to have a issue tracking / ticket managing system for the entire team, not just the software.  So, anyone with experience, I would love to hear what your team does.

link_counts.title: Jira Usage in FRC Team Organization

posts.name: RoboLancers 321 | LANCE-A-LOT 427 | FIRST Business Development Manager
posts.cooked: We’ve invested heavily into Notion this year, and we’re rather happy with it. We have mini-wikis, project / task tracking, a fabrication queue for each machine, etc. @tinaaa21 and @BananasAmIRite are two of the students that lead the process of selecting Notion over other tools, and then developed the systems around it, and can speak more to specifics.
posts.display_username: RoboLancers 321 | LANCE-A-LOT 427 | FIRST Business Development Manager

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
I’ve used Jira professionally.  It kicked my butt professionally.  I would not use it for an FRC team.

I’ve had more success with Trello (which I hear is tightening its free plan, RIP legend).  We’ve also done massive omnibus Google Docs in the past, which are better than nothing–especially when you’re getting started and still feeling out your actual workflow.

As it sits, we’re auditioning Github’s project tools since we already have an organization and have to use Github for code so it’s a cheap lift.  We like it so far but it’s still early days.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.custom_user_title: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: We have used Notion extensively, and we have run into some big issues with edit protections.  Our workspace has become unwieldy, and we have had ongoing problems with our education / student plan that have severely broken our documents.  Moreover, the open-endedness of notion has lead to no one knowing how it should be used.  I’d like to hear how you use it though.

reply_to_user.name: RoboLancers 321 | LANCE-A-LOT 427 | FIRST Business Development Manager

posts.name: Anthony.Uri
posts.cooked: I’ve been using Jira for years professionally and would never attempt to bring it into FRC . I am personally a big fan of Team Gantt , and they will issue free pro licenses if you contact them (in my experience).

posts.name: asa
posts.cooked:
How does your team intend to use github projects for non-programming tasks? We considered it but the additional hurdle of getting mechanical and electrical on board was deemed too much of an issue.

We’re currently switching from linear to microsoft planner because linear was too complex for full team buy-in. (our school district pays for office 365 that they’re trying to force us to use anyway)

link_counts.title: Linear – A better way to build products

posts.name: Fritz G
posts.cooked:
We used jira this year and were pretty happy with it. That being said we are lucky enough to be able to pick the brains of some people from amazon who use it daily, which helped a lot to flatten out the very steep learning curve. Jira is a very powerful tool, and we barely scratch the surface of what it can do.

here’s some more details about our setup:

each sprint is one week

we have 10 minute standup meetings for leadership at the beginning of every team meeting (designed to spin off into smaller discussions where necessary) to discuss the status of tasks and prioritize the agenda for the day

tasks are all high level (eg more like “cut drive rail” than “cut a piece of 1/8” wall 2x1 to 18"). This allows our leads to still utilize their preferred management tool (eg github issues for prog, whiteboard with parts for fab)

we have a very large team (well over 100 members), I think this setup would be very overkill for the average team

each ticket is assigned to an epic (either a robot subsystem or one of the generic tasks such as “orders” or “organization”)

for example, here’s what our board looked like at the end of build week 1: image 2574×1388 357 KB image 2570×988 261 KB

image 2574×1388 357 KB

image 2574×1388 357 KB

image 2570×988 261 KB

image 2570×988 261 KB

edit: I also talked a bit with Josh from 6324 here about how they use jira

link_counts.title: FRC 6324 The Blue Devils | 2024 Build Thread

posts.name: Michael Ray
posts.cooked:
Valor uses Jira to manage parts ordering, as well as for our manufacturing process. We have been using this system since our rookie year in 2018, and it has evolved over time. Disclaimer: It took a bit to setup, and I am very fluent already in Jira as I use it for work (software engineer at Amazon).

When a student wants to order a part, they log in and create an issue with a type of “Part”. The screen is as follows:

image 813×702 17.4 KB

image 813×702 17.4 KB

image 813×702 17.4 KB

Summary: Human readable item name

Epic: Which subsystem the item belongs to

Priority: When do we need it by? Is it urgent?

Rest is self explanatory…

When the students complete the items, it goes into a column for the mentors to review. When the mentors review, they can approve or reject. Once approved, it goes to me and I forward the items to our booster purchaser (I have a button I click to export to CSV which gets opened in Excel from our purchaser). The flow is as follows:

image 2077×1046 129 KB

image 2077×1046 129 KB

image 2077×1046 129 KB

When the items arrive, a mentor (usually me) moves the items into the Delivered column and then I put the parts in the Epic / Assembly bins that we have. The kids get an email that I moved the ticket and they know if they are not at the shop yet that their parts are here!

When an assembly is ready to go in Onshape, the students can use a custom webpage I built which transfers the items in OnShape (via the Bill of Materials APIs) into Jira! This is the game changing part - making tickets would take forever or a dedicated Project Manager without it. It automatically defaults some machinery, material, powdercoat, etc. from the attributes associated with the part in CAD. The tool also allows the students to change it quickly before creating the ticket. Here is what the tool looks like:

image 2532×910 158 KB

image 2532×910 158 KB

image 2532×910 158 KB

Once the student hits “Save Changes”, the CAD students job is over! Our dedicated manufacturing team is now control of the parts and they can make and assemble independently.

Students can also create parts manually if they desire (quick prototyping, simple parts without CAD, etc.)

image 815×716 19 KB

image 815×716 19 KB

image 815×716 19 KB

Manufacturing students when they get to the shop look at the “Ready” column and see what parts are available. They can choose parts that they individually want to make or are good at. We have filters that let them identify Mill vs Lathe parts, and also have swimlanes for seeing which parts are highest priority. Metadata on the ticket shows them the material thickness, which machinery, and the material. Router students are good at finding all the parts that have the same thickness and material so they can bulk manufacture. The board looks like:

image 2482×1138 128 KB

image 2482×1138 128 KB

image 2482×1138 128 KB

Students pull tickets and assign their name. They move them into the In Progress column. Once the part is made and needs to be powdercoated, they move it to Post Process for our powder coat gurus to pick up and handle. Finally, the part goes to Mentor Approval where the mentors provide feedback and QA. When an Epic (i.e. Assembly) is finished, the kids can assemble.

I have some dashboards that help me understand how the shop is moving and the state our parts are in. We have graphs and tables for pretty much everything. My favorite are the bar charts:

image 780×692 19 KB

image 780×692 19 KB

image 780×692 19 KB

image 780×1168 34.4 KB

image 780×1168 34.4 KB

image 780×1168 34.4 KB

I actually used these charts a few years back to pitch to our board and school that we needed more routers. 40% of our parts were going onto the routers, and I showcased the total man hours we spent on the routers to illustrate we needed more of them. We purchased 2 more Lagunas that summer!

The filtering and searching is pretty good once you learn. I can query for lets say any parts orders from WCP that were approved and not purchased yet, and then use our KOP voucher on kickoff to buy those parts (that is just a random example, but you get the point!)

image 1728×343 19.7 KB

image 1728×343 19.7 KB

image 1728×343 19.7 KB

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
Lots of versions of sprint or task based tracking/planning apps out there (mentioned above) that can be good with the right level of adoption for a team.

Jira is probably the least user friendly and least fun option. There are some marginal benefits that Jira is “more common” in industry, but those don’t outweigh the pain.

posts.name: Michael Ray
posts.cooked:
Valor also uses GitLab for Software Project management. We used to use Jira, but we wanted more tie-ins with our source code. Jira has plugins for that, but then our school blocked GitHub so therefore the switch to GitLab was an easy option.

We begin by defining our “User Stories” - aka what do our drivers and team want by the end of the season. In the image below, we defined 2 of them which are marked in the red boxes. For each user story, we start to define the tasks that are needed to complete that story. We keep making tasks and more tasks until eventually we are left with individual tasks that all lead up to our end goal. We call this a “dependency tree”, and is critical to how we drive towards our goals

image 1441×1191 54.6 KB

image 1441×1191 54.6 KB

image 1441×1191 54.6 KB

Once all the tasks are outlined, we connect the dots to illustrate the dependencies. We then draw boundaries between the dependencies - those are our epics. We enter those epics into GitLab and create an issue for each white box in GitLab under the epic

Epics:

image 589×667 60.2 KB

image 589×667 60.2 KB

image 589×667 60.2 KB

Issues:

image 1262×975 53.2 KB

image 1262×975 53.2 KB

image 1262×975 53.2 KB

We then define milestones for when we want certain epics done. The milestones get created in GitLab, and the issues/epics get assigned to each milestone:

image 1276×742 93.6 KB

image 1276×742 93.6 KB

image 1276×742 93.6 KB

Dates are defined for the milestone which then creates a roadmap:

image 1035×566 47.6 KB

image 1035×566 47.6 KB

image 1035×566 47.6 KB

This is a little more like Waterfall development rather than Agile development, but it still can be dealt with in a Kanban board and slowly worked on. This also helps the kids move forward week over week without having a physical robot in front of them to work on in the early parts of the season

posts.name: Wyatt
posts.cooked: Our team uses Basecamp and it works really well for us. We use a Kanban setup for build/CAD (I’m a CAD lead, so can’t really speak to how it works for code). It’s fantastic for compartmentalized communication; makes it very easy to set up projects and teams so you can stay in the loop with things you’re involved in, but keep away from unwanted clutter that doesn’t affect you much. And its free for education!!

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: I love this!  Is there a github equivalent?  Also, what tool do you use for visualizing dependencies?  I would love to see your workflow in-depth!

Could you elaborate more on the edit protections and broken documents issues? We used one member account this year with 100+ guest accounts and didn’t run into those issues. We set up Notion classes this year towards the end of last offseason and had a few Notion “experts” help answer questions/keep leads accountable with using Notion.

This thread has a general gist of how we used Notion this year!

Notion vs Monday General Forum

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Your solution of having everyone but the manager be a guest might be a solution for us.  Our issues came from wanting to protect everything possible and so assigning everyone’s permissions uniquely, which, combined with exceeding the block limit, seemed to break our whole workspace?  I’m not really sure how it all went down, but I know our school got involved and tried to change our plan to education, and that didn’t work for some reason.  In any case, our current state is that no one can add or remove collaborators and we can exceed the block limit.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: @s3529 recommended Slack Lists, and after looking into it quite a bit, I would definitely recommend it as well.  It is newly being included in Slack Pro and above, and is a great all-in-one replacement for Trello or another project management software.  If you’re thinking about paying for Slack for your team (abt $300 per year for 20 people with the edu discount but don’t quote me on that) it’s definitely worth a look.

posts.name: Robertson Robotics
posts.cooked:
Slack also offers a free plan to nonprofits which is pretty great.

The Slack for Nonprofits program offers free or discounted plan upgrades to eligible organizations. Here are the details:   Pro Plan: We offer workspaces with 250 or fewer members a free upgrade, ...

The Slack for Education program offers an 85% discount on our Pro or Business+ paid plans. To see the non-discounted cost per member in your currency, head to our pricing page. If your application ...
